V.Action: Fully dresses in distinctive cloak, hat, and mask with a carefully crafted aesthetic, indicating purposeful and skillful self-presentation.
Gazes into the mirror confidently, suggesting self-awareness and calculated identity management.
Walking with steady boots opposite of Evey on a dark street, implying intentional movement and purpose.
Interrupts the assault on Evey to confront the Fingermen.
Interrupts the attack on Evey with timely and confident intervention.
Uses literary quotations to unnerve and distract opponents.
Attacks and incapacitates the Fingermen violently to protect Evey.
Scoops Evey up and carries her away to protect her from the arriving authorities.
Responds to Evey's question about helping her with an enigmatic 'Why indeed?'
Introduces himself mysteriously as 'the villain' but bows politely to Evey.
Kills 3 armed Fingermen swiftly and with superior speed and skill, incapacitating them before they can react.
Uses a concealed knife with precision, removing it before bodies fall, demonstrating careful planning and execution.
Remains calm and composed, showing confidence in a dangerous confrontation.
Successfully escapes with Evey while sirens approach, using the environment (alleyway) to disappear from pursuers.
Speaks theatrically and cryptically with Evey but answers questions skillfully to maintain control of the situation.
Uses a symbolic act of conducting musical 'music' to set a dramatic, impactful scene marking an important historical moment, demonstrating thoughtful preparation and control.
Engages Evey with deliberate, meaningful dialogue to prepare her for what is to come, showing strategic interpersonal skill.
Appears confident and assured while orchestrating the moment, indicating strong self-confidence and command.
Smiles while orchestrating a massive explosion and destruction, showing delight in violence.
Responds politely and simply with 'Thank you' when Evey compliments the fireworks display, showing some courteousness.
Coordinates a precise and theatrical destruction of Big Ben and the statue of justice with accompanying music and fireworks, demonstrating careful planning and execution.
Maintains composure and smiles during the operation, showing confidence.
Leads Evey by her fingertips while she is blindfolded, guiding her gently as if dancing.
Allows Evey to reach out after slipping fingers free, reassuring her she hasn't lost him.
Reveals his home and collection of art and culture to Evey, inviting her to stay with him.
Addresses Evey kindly and smiles when she returns his smile.
Jumps from the bridge onto the moving train in a cloak, moving stealthily and confidently.
Quietly checks on Evey while she is asleep, demonstrating care and discretion.
Jumps onto a speeding train and kills bodyguards with lethal force, creating fear and chaos.
Sits calmly and smiles enigmatically after violent actions, refusing to explain or engage emotionally with Prothero.
Jumps onto a moving train at high speed, demonstrating physical agility and daring.
Silently disables the train brakes, plunging the train car into darkness, showing tactical skill and planning.
Kills the bodyguards efficiently and without hesitation, demonstrating combat effectiveness.
Sits casually and confidently across from Prothero after violent action, showing composure and control.
Allows the train car occupants to realize his identity and the consequences of his actions, indicating psychological insight and intimidation tactics.
Offers Prothero a choice rather than immediately killing him.
Mentions Prothero's role in the horrors at Larkhill, indicating a focus on justice rather than personal vendetta.
Confronts Prothero, forces him to inject himself with an unknown substance, threatening to kill him otherwise.
Calmly confronts Prothero, asserts control with measured threats and a calculated psychological approach.
Effectively uses intimidation and logical choice framing to dominate and confuse Prothero.
Employs patience and confidence rather than impulsiveness in a high-stakes encounter.
Presses a gun to Prothero's forehead, forces him to inject a lethal syringe, reminds him of past cruelty.
Shows a moment of understanding of Prothero's fear and difficult choice.
Presses gun to Prothero’s forehead and commands him to make a difficult choice, using psychological pressure effectively.
Calmly explains the gravity of the situation and presents a choice that manipulates Prothero into an act of self-injection.
Keeps composure and uses prior knowledge of Prothero’s behavior to break his will.
Recites and explains a Latin quotation with confidence and contextual relevance.
Engages Evey in a thoughtful conversation about responsibility and conquering one's universe, showing emotional and intellectual insight.
Refuses to make a deal unless Evey genuinely wants one, demonstrating control and clear boundaries.
Hints at a plan by saying he knows a way Evey can help him soon, indicating confidence and foresight.
Refers to Dr. John Faust as 'nobody you'd have heard of,' which is a subtle misinformation since Faust is a well-known literary figure; this could be seen as either clever or evasive.
Emerges suddenly through the fog and kills two guards without hesitation.
Rushed into the courtyard immediately after killing guards, showing decisiveness but no indication of sympathy for them.
Bows politely before confronting Lilliman and presses a finger to his smile to silence him
Points a knife at Lilliman's throat, clearly threatening him
Explains to Evey that death is a consequence of Lilliman's own actions, showing no hesitation in killing him
Confronts and intimidates Lilliman with knife at throat calmly and confidently.
Uses precise timing to appear suddenly and stop Lilliman's charge.
Controls the situation with composed speech and gestures (bows, finger to smile).
Kills Lilliman deliberately despite Evey's protests, showing decisiveness.
Answers Delia's question calmly and confidently, affirming intent to kill her.
Kills all other implicated individuals efficiently, leaving only Delia surviving.
Appears suspended in the shadows with controlled presence, suggesting strategic stealth.
Listens quietly and attentively to Delia Surridge's confession and emotional pain without interrupting or judging.
Maintains a silent, observing presence without providing comfort or reassurance to Delia during her emotional turmoil.
Floats silently and watches Delia as she confesses her guilt and torment without interrupting, showing control and patience.
Maintains a calm and confident presence (hovering, smiling mask) that reassures Delia and encourages her confession.
Gives Delia a rose and calmly reassures her that her death will be painless.
Kills Delia while she sleeps but ensures no pain and offers a final moment of connection by revealing his face.
Administers a painless, covert lethal injection to Delia while she sleeps, demonstrating careful planning and precision.
Calmly reveals his face to Delia, maintaining control over the emotional moment, showing confidence.
Quietly shuts the door to avoid waking Delia and faces an armed adversary calmly, showing situational awareness and self-control.
Confronted by Derek Almond who threatens him with a gun, V stands firm with only knives and martial skills, implying preparedness and confidence despite the threat.
Embraces Derek tightly before stabbing him, causing intense fear and pain.
Removes his own mask to confront Derek more directly during the attack.
Surprises and incapacitates Derek quickly and skillfully with a knife strike from a close embrace, demonstrating tactical stealth and combat proficiency.
Allows Derek to rip off his mask during a close combat encounter, potentially compromising his secret identity.
Sits silently staring, unaffected by others' fear and superstition around him.
Proficiently engages in gardening project, showing ability to nurture growth.
Displays calm and silent presence while being observed as insane, demonstrating controlled and deliberate behavior despite others' fear.
Engages in gardening project showing proficiency, indicating skill and capability beyond assumptions about his mental state.
Does not attempt to communicate or resist despite being closely watched and judged by others, maintaining inscrutability.
Emerges on the screen with a smiling face during Evey's interrogation, indirectly providing hope or reassurance.
Remains unmoving and silent during Evey's interrogation, not intervening to protect her from tormentors.
Emerges confidently on the screen during Evey's interrogation, maintaining a calm and smiling demeanor despite the hostile situation.
Acts as a protector of Evey, involving her in his plan to expose corruption and injustice.
Is implicated in killings (Delia Surridge and Derek Almond) with Evey's help.
Successfully orchestrates the abduction, imprisonment, and psychological manipulation of Evey to prepare her for their goals.
Maintains psychological control indirectly over Evey through careful planning and manipulation rather than direct intervention in this scene.
Allows the Interrogator to lose effectiveness as Evey refuses to comply with signing a false confession, indicating indirect competence in breaking the will of opponents through prior conditioning.
Welcomes Evey back to the Shadow Gallery after her imprisonment and torture.
Inflicts physical harm and psychological torture on Evey without her prior knowledge.
Approaches Evey quietly as she struggles emotionally, showing calm and controlled demeanor.
Tells Evey 'Because I love you' and 'I wanted to set you free.'
Inflicts psychological torture on Evey to forcibly free her from her mental prison.
Insists that Evey was already in a prison and tries to open her eyes to reality, despite her anger and disgust.
Calmly and confidently explains to Evey the purpose behind his painful actions, revealing a broader, strategic perspective on freedom and imprisonment.
Engages in a psychological confrontation with Evey, showing skill in challenging her beliefs and provoking self-reflection despite her anger and distress.
Cradles Evey as she hyperventilates, encourages her to face her fear and accept freedom.
Helps Evey physically, gently lifts her, and supports her through a terrifying process.
Calms Evey during a panic attack, helping her confront and overcome deep fear.
Provides clear guidance and physical support to Evey while she undergoes a traumatic emotional and psychological process.
Encourages Evey to face her fears directly instead of avoiding them, demonstrating confidence in the process and in her ability.
Encourages Evey to embrace the storm naked, urging her to seize the night and be transformed by it.
Leads Evey through a transformative, symbolic ritual in adverse conditions, demonstrating confidence and purposeful guidance.
Does not physically intervene to protect Evey from the storm but trusts the process of her transformation.
Plays piano a Bach concerto gracefully.
Responds to Evey's gratitude by acknowledging her own strength and attributing success to her.
Plays a complex piano concerto gracefully and confidently while engaging with Evey in a calm and supportive manner.
Acknowledges Evey's personal growth and contribution rather than taking all credit himself, demonstrating emotional intelligence and self-awareness.
Shows Evey Valerie's room, explaining the origin of the letter and sharing the story of Valerie’s life and death.
Grows roses for Valerie and tends to her shrine.
Admits to not writing the letter Evey cherished, instead delivering Valerie's words.
Leads Evey to a secret, personal place and shares the deepest part of his home with her.
Gives Evey a tour and shows her a beautiful antique train car, indicating trust and openness.
Fills the train car with gelignite and calmly tells Evey, causing her fear.
Leads Evey confidently through a secret, complex underground passage, demonstrating knowledge of his environment and control.
Possesses an antique train filled with explosives and plans to use them strategically against the government.
Keeps his plans partially mysterious but shows clear intention to 'finish what was started four hundred years ago,' indicating a long-term vision and focus.
Smiles upon entering the loading bay, disarms multiple guards who go for their weapons.
Plans to ask others to turn on the underground power despite it being shut down for years, showing calculated confidence.
Enters a loading bay where guards are armed and ready to attack, calmly facing the situation with a smile and action readiness.
Attacks several guards brutally and with superhuman power.
Stops and surrenders when faced with multiple armed guards.
Uses superhuman strength and skill to brutally and quickly incapacitate multiple opponents.
Emerges from elevator and immediately attacks more guards, quickly disabling them.
Confronted by multiple guards with weapons trained on him, appears to surrender but reveals enough explosives to destroy the building.
Calmly addresses London publicly via television, initiating dialogue with the populace.
Follows Roger Dascombe into a control booth to hand him a videotape, implying intention to communicate or reveal something.
Surrounded and appearing to surrender, reveals explosives capable of massive destruction.
Reveals large amount of TNT and holds detonator calmly while surrounded by guards, demonstrating control of a dangerous situation.
Follows Roger Dascombe into control booth unnoticed and discreetly hands over a videotape, indicating stealth and careful planning.
Appears calmly on television broadcasting a message, showing confidence and control of communication.
Smiles at the horrified Adam Susan before beginning his broadcast.
Speaks directly to the public about truth, injustice, and individual power during a tense situation.
Uses a calm and somewhat theatrical tone ('Are you sitting comfortably? Good.') despite the threat of violence.
Delivers a calculated, confident public broadcast directly challenging a powerful leader and addressing the public, anticipating military response and using it to emphasize his message.
Smiles calmly at the horrified leader, showing psychological control and composure under threat.
Offers the people a deal for a better world without oppression and surveillance, emphasizing individual power and a second chance.
Calls for people to join together to witness the destruction of the old regime and the start of a new day.
Delivers a confident and articulate broadcast directly challenging the regime, demonstrating clear strategic intent.
Offers the public a visionary and well-structured plan for change, indicating foresight and persuasive communication skills.
Coordinates a timed, symbolic act of destruction to rally public attention and signal the start of revolution.
Addresses the public personally, speaking directly and inclusively ('To know me any more you need only look to a mirror').
Invites the crowd to hope for a future meeting and bids them goodnight, showing a courteous and hopeful tone.
Enters alone into a dangerous situation seemingly ready to confront death.
Occupies the control booth alone, appearing confident despite overwhelming enemy forces.
Prepared for gunfire and reacts with fluid movement, minimizing damage.
Deliberately sacrifices himself creating ambiguity by substituting his identity with another (Roger Dascombe).
Masters psychological manipulation through broadcasted messages to influence public perception and enemy behavior.
Uses media (VTV) effectively to communicate and psychologically influence the public and government agents.
Maintains a confident and enigmatic demeanor by smiling directly at the audience on the recording.
Communicates cryptic messages on tape intended to provoke thought and action.
Engages Helen Heyer with calculated psychological manipulation via media.
Intelligently negotiates by offering information in exchange for the 'line of the Queen,' demonstrating strategic thinking and confident interaction.
Calmly changes the radio frequency on request without hesitation, showing control over the environment and awareness.
Nods almost laughing at the irony of the broadcast, demonstrating confidence and a clear understanding of the situation.
Creates and sends a provocative, manipulative tape that successfully destabilizes Conrad, leading to a loss of control and a crash.
Remains hidden and stealthy after luring Finch into the train car full of explosives, demonstrating control of the situation.
Explains to Evey that change is necessary, answers sincerely and patiently.
Acknowledges that change will be violent but does not glorify violence, shows frankness and seriousness.
Maintains a mysterious and distant demeanor, not directly comforting Evey beyond factual answers.
Asks Evey to dance despite never having done so before, shows vulnerability and trust.
Dances closely and tenderly with Evey, sharing an intimate and sincere moment.
Successfully kills Conrad and Creedy using a hammer and knife in close combat, demonstrating tactical violence and precision.
Operates the jukebox to play a specific melancholic song at the exact moment of violent acts, showing careful planning and symbolic integration of actions.
Engages emotionally and vulnerably by asking Evey to dance, admitting he's never danced before, revealing personal insecurities.
Maintains composure in the face of violence and afterward, indicating confident control over circumstances.
Calmly says goodbye to Evey with confidence, reassuring her with a promise to return despite imminent danger.
Uses a secret passage to ambush or evade a large force of soldiers in a well-planned manner.
Ambushes and kills soldiers with brutal efficiency in the tunnels.
Uses a voice broadcast to address the citizens of London, offering them a chance to change.
Ambushes and swiftly kills five soldiers with great speed and skill, disappears without a trace.
Uses darkness and cloak effectively to remain concealed, attacking like a 'grinning dervish' with precise knife strikes.
Implements psychological warfare by broadcasting a message through hidden speakers to demoralize and intimidate enemies.
Addresses soldiers directly, urging them to consider their families and choose freedom over blind loyalty.
Kills the Captain who orders retreat and disobedience, showing no hesitation.
Delivers a strategic, confident speech over the communication system, psychologically persuading enemy soldiers to desert and thereby weakening the opposition without direct combat.
Uses timed distractions and precise assassinations (killing the Captain silently) to maintain control over the situation and ensure orderly progression of plans.
Mocks and threatens the Leader with cold insults, wounds him with a knife.
Acknowledges that the Leader gave him purpose, indicating a complex recognition of origin.
Drops the knife when commanded by Finch, showing restraint and obedience.
Thanks Mr. Finch before his death and says goodbye to him.
Kills Finch after Finch refuses to shoot V as ordered.
Survives a surprise attack by the Leader despite being shot and manages to continue moving forward to pick up the knife, demonstrating confidence and physical resilience.
Engages in a psychological exchange with the Leader, showing calmness and confidence under threat.
Allows Finch to refuse to kill him, seemingly predicting or manipulating the situation to his advantage.
Smiles and proclaims 'ideas are bulletproof' before killing the Leader who is a violent authoritarian figure.
Continues advancing calmly and deliberately toward the Leader despite being shot at and knocked back, showing resilience and control under fire.
Moves forward with short deliberate steps while bullets shred his cloak, demonstrating focused confidence and strategy in a life-threatening situation.
Smiles and confidently declares that he is an idea, bulletproof, displaying high intelligence and psychological dominance.
Successfully kills the Leader with a precise knife thrust into his heart, ending the confrontation efficiently.
Returns to Evey despite injury, allowing her to see him and speak to him.
Collapses and struggles down the stairs, showing vulnerability to Evey.
Speaks sincerely to Evey about his fate and unfinished business, showing openness.
Does not call for outside help or maintain distance; instead lets Evey hold him.
Returns despite serious injury, manages to fulfill mission objectives before collapsing.
Admits physical vulnerability and impending death openly, demonstrating self-awareness and prioritizing important communication.
Rolls down stairs while injured, which could be seen as loss of control but also suggests determination to reach Evey.
Reaches up and wipes a tear from Evey's cheek.
Expresses love to Evey and asks for a promise to protect his secret.
Refers to himself as the villain and destroyer, distancing himself from trustworthiness.
Keeps promise to Evey despite inevitable death, shows calm acceptance and emotional control in final moments.
Encourages Evey to discover the face under the mask but never look beneath it, demonstrating strategic thinking and awareness of symbolism.
Asks Evey to make promises crucial for future success, showing trust in others and foresight.
Declares self a villain and destroyer, perhaps revealing self-awareness but also resignation; not a negative competence indicator in this context.
Expresses emotional vulnerability openly (wiping tear, asking to hear music one last time), showing humanity but might be viewed as potentially undermining a purely stoic competent image.
Encourages Evey to keep faith in him despite apparent death, expressing knowledge of her loyalty ('I know you won't... I know.')
Maintains mystery by insisting no one will ever see the face beneath the mask
Maintains a mysterious composure by ensuring his true face remains hidden, controlling the narrative about his identity.
Leaves his fate ambiguous, fostering hope and commitment in Evey despite appearing lifeless.
Allows Evey to tenderly kiss his mask and says farewell indirectly, showing trust and affection.
Leaves behind a symbolic gesture (the gelignite bed covered in roses) that inspires hope and freedom in others.
Uses dramatic and symbolic means (self-sacrifice and inspiring revolution) rather than direct personal connection.
Arranges his own death with a symbolic and strategic finale, using gelignite and roses to create a powerful statement.
Leaves the continuation of his mission to Evey, showing foresight and trust in her ability to carry on his legacy.
Does not physically appear in the final scenes, delegating public action to Evey, which could be seen as an omission of direct leadership.
Speaks tenderly to Evey, expressing a wish to experience the music one last time, sharing a private, intimate moment.
Plans and executes the destruction of a government building by orchestrating a train crash and timed explosion, demonstrating meticulous preparation and control over complex events.
Uses a deeply symbolic and psychological approach, including music and timing, to heighten the impact of the event, reflecting intelligent and confident leadership.
